subject: Re: How to write effective tests?
msgSnippet: Hi, There is test case design tool named Orchid developed by stagsoftware,a bangalore based testing company,which will help us to design effective and
messageBody:
Hi,

There is test case design tool named 'Orchid' developed by
stagsoftware,a bangalore based testing company,which will help us to
design effective and minimal number of test cases.
their site is,www.stagsoftware.com
thanks,
san
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Lee Chalupa <lchalupa@s...> wrote:
>
> Can anyone point me towards a book that give some practical
insights into
> the thinking process a programmer goes through to write a good set
of
> tests?
>
> Thanks
>
> lee
>
>
>
> On Tue, 21 Jan 2003 11:41:47 +0900 (JST), Curt Sampson
<yahoo_sucks@c...>
> wrote:
>
> > <html><body>
> >
> >
> > <tt>
> > On Mon, 20 Jan 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:<BR>
> > <BR>
> > > Generally speaking, you don't really know these things until
you
> > write<BR>
> > > test code, which is really just sample client code, look at
it,<BR>
> > > evaluate it and move on. In general, it is when one sees it
"in
> > print"<BR>
> > > than one really looks at it carefully. Writing the test
first<BR>
> > > guarantees this, while writing the stub first does not.<BR>
> > <BR>
> > Actually, another point I forgot to mention is that writing the
> > testing<BR>
> > code first gets you writing testable code faster. I know that
when
> > I'm<BR>
> > writing unit tests for legacy code, I frequently have to change
the<BR>
> > design of the code so I can test it more easily.<BR>
> > <BR>
> > cjs<BR>
> > -- <BR>
> > Curt Sampson  cjs@c...   +81 90 7737
> > 2974   <a
> > href="http://www.netbsd.org">http://www.netbsd.org</a><BR>
> >     Don't you know, in this new Dark Age, we're
all
> > light.  --XTC<BR>
> > <BR>
> > <BR>
> > </tt>
> >
> > <br>
